abstract:
The Nez Perce Tribe's Department of Fisheries Resources Management (DFRM) gathers data from various hatchery facilities to monitor the health and productivity of their fish populations. These facilities include adult traps, weirs, holding ponds, spawning sites, juvenile rearing locations, and release sites. The tribe manages each site independently, collaboratively with co-managers, or in an assisting role. This method is specific to the unique characteristics of each hatchery, fish species, and run timing.

The necessity of this data collection lies in ensuring the sustainable management and conservation of Nez Perce Tribe's fishery resources. By monitoring the health and productivity of their fish populations at different stages of their life cycle, the DFRM can make informed decisions to improve hatchery practices, mitigate potential threats, and adapt to changing environmental conditions.

The data collected from each site is essential in addressing several issues, such as:
- Ensuring the quality and quantity of fish stock for both subsistence and commercial purposes
- Identifying and addressing any diseases or parasites affecting fish populations
- Evaluating the success of hatchery rearing programs and adjusting practices accordingly
- Collaborating with co-managers and other stakeholders to maintain sustainable fisheries and aquatic ecosystems

In summary, this data collection method enables the Nez Perce Tribe to effectively manage their fishery resources by monitoring fish populations at various stages of their life cycle and addressing any issues that may arise. It is a crucial component in maintaining the health, productivity, and sustainability of their fisheries for future generations.

description:
The Nez Perce Tribe (NPT) Department of Fisheries Resources Management (DFRM) gathers hatchery evaluation data from various facilities, specifically numbering eighteen. These facilities encompass different types, namely adult traps, picket weirs, adult holding ponds, spawning facilities, primary and secondary juvenile rearing locations, and acclimation release sites.

At each site, the Nez Perce Tribe (NPT) independently manages the operations. In certain cases, collaboration with co-managers is necessary or NPT assumes an assistive role. The methodology employed for data collection varies depending on the specific hatchery, fish species, and run-timing.

Adult traps refer to physical structures used to capture mature fish. Picket weirs are another type of facility that utilizes a weir, typically constructed from wooden stakes and catch netting, to trap adult fish as they migrate upstream. In contrast, adult holding ponds serve as temporary containment areas for mature fish before or after their release into the wild.

Spawning facilities are essential in the reproductive process of fish. These sites provide controlled environments where fish can spawn and lay eggs, ensuring a consistent population for hatcheries. Primary and secondary juvenile rearing locations refer to areas specifically designed for the growth and development of young fish before their eventual release into the wild.

Lastly, acclimation release sites allow for the gradual adjustment of young fish to natural environmental conditions prior to being released into their native waters. The Nez Perce Tribe's DFRM collects detailed information from each of these facilities, tailoring the data collection process to the unique characteristics and requirements of each hatchery, fish species, and run-timing.
